PostValue.explanation: This is a useful, practical post for the EA/rationalist community—especially event organisers and regional chapter staff—because it documents lessons, metrics, and operational best practices that can improve future EAGx events and local community-building. However its claims aren’t load-bearing for core EA cause prioritization or longtermist theory; if the report’s conclusions were wrong it would mainly affect conference efficiency and attendee experience rather than high‑stakes decisions. For general humanity it is effectively trivial.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Financial transparency is unclear and likely to confuse readers — fix before publishing. The report shows a large mismatch between the total event grant (AUD $303,837), planned expenditure ($223,700) and actual spend to date ($128,509), plus a stated cost-per-attendee ($749.50) with no clear formula or line-item breakdown. Actionable fixes: add a short, explicit budget table that reconciles grant vs planned vs actual, lists major line items (venue, catering, AV, travel support, staff costs, merch, contingencies), states what is excluded from each figure, explains how cost-per-attendee was calculated, and says what will happen to underspent funds. This avoids obvious “own-goal” questions about stewardship and accounting.  

2) The report emphasises outputs and satisfaction but lacks outcome/impact metrics — readers will reasonably ask “so what changed?” Actionable fixes: include at least one concrete section explaining how you evaluate impact (short list of measurable outcomes you tracked or plan to track), e.g. 3–6 month follow-up survey on attendee actions (projects started, hires, donations, collaborations), number of meaningful new connections (mentorships or ongoing groups), and any concrete community wins. If these data don’t exist yet, say so and commit to a follow-up plan and template survey so future organisers can reuse it.  

3) Representation, accessibility and attendance shortfall are under-analysed — the report reports % women (27%) and % first-timers (26%) and notes attendance missed target, but gives little investigation into causes or mitigations. Actionable fixes: add a short diagnostic on why attendance was below target (timing, pricing, venue, marketing channels, overlap with other events), acknowledge survey response rate and potential biases (127/259), and add specific recommendations for improving diversity and accessibility (e.g. budget for travel/stipends, single central venue vs multi-site tradeoffs, targeted outreach channels, transport/access notes). Even 1–2 paragraphs here will head off predictable critiques and make the report far more useful to other organisers.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback identifies major, legitimate weaknesses readers will notice (an unexplained large funding mismatch, no impact/outcome metrics, and under-analysed attendance/diversity issues). These are the kinds of ‘own-goal’ mistakes that undermine trust and usefulness and are straightforward to fix with concise additions (a reconciled budget table; a brief outcomes/metrics section or commitment to follow-up; a short diagnostics paragraph on attendance and diversity). Fixing them would substantially improve the report without requiring excessive length.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I cannot identify a notable EA/rationalist figure or public author known as “Bridget L 🔸.” This appears to be a pseudonym or a minor/anonymous online handle; there are no widely known publications, talks, or leadership roles under that name in EA/rationalist communities or in the broader public record. If they publish under a different full name, their prominence could be different.

PostClarity.explanation: Overall very clear and well-structured: a short intro, clear signposts for how to engage with the full report, a concise AI-written executive summary, and a useful data table. Strengths: good headings, links, clear calls-to-action, and helpful metrics. Weaknesses: minor grammatical slips (“There’s a few ways”), some visual/table formatting is slightly cluttered or inconsistent, and the post leans on an external 68‑page document for most detail (so readers must follow links to get full context).

PostNovelty.explanation: This is mainly an operational post: a post‑mortem/public report for a regional conference. For EA Forum readers, such reports, metrics (attendance, budget, survey scores), and modest innovations (multi‑venue format, 'open discussions corner', stewardship/buddy programme, book‑focused merch) are familiar and unsurprising, so novelty is low. For the general public the specific EA framing and some event design details are slightly less common but still broadly ordinary conference/organising ideas, so novelty is only marginally higher.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: The report is logically structured and transparent: it states clear goals, presents relevant operational metrics (attendance, budget, sessions, survey scores), acknowledges successes and failures, and draws sensible recommendations. However, evidence is mostly descriptive and short‑term (attendance and post‑event survey data, n=127), with limited baseline/comparative context, potential response/selection bias, few causal claims tested, and little longitudinal or outcome data on longer‑term impact. The result is a credible, practical case that the event met its core aims operationally, but weaker support for claims about lasting impact or the reasons behind some outcomes (e.g. large underspend, lower attendance).

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most of the post’s key empirical claims (event dates, venue, organiser names, and the headline metrics) are documented in the organisers’ public materials and an attached public report, and the event page confirms date/venue. However, many of the quantitative figures (attendance breakdowns, budget/expenditure, survey responses and ratings, cost-per-attendee, % first-timers/% women, and core team hours) are self-reported in the organisers’ report and EA Forum post and do not appear to have independent third‑party verification or auditing available online. I found no evidence contradicting the organisers’ numbers, but independent confirmation (e.g., audited accounts, venue/AV receipts, or CEA/EAA third‑party summaries) is absent — so the claims are plausible and well-documented by primary sources but not independently validated, hence a score of 7.
sources: EA Forum post: "EAGxAustralasia 2024 Public Report" — Bridget L (28 Mar 2025), Effective Altruism / EA Forum. (https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/eax9pf3eHmKesdKvx/eagxaustralasia-2024-public-report).
EAGxAustralasia 2024 Report [Public] — Google Docs (organisers’ full 68‑page report). (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1eKVj9OsATLLkAHrHjQ-nn8BYQina5zYf5-n7XAI-4Fk/edit).
Event listing: "EAGxAustralasia 2024" — EffectiveAltruism.com events page (confirms dates and venues: Nov 22–24, 2024; Aerial UTS, Sydney).
Effective Altruism Australia — About / Staff (confirms Bridget Loughhead’s role and involvement in organising EAGx).
EAGxAustralia 2023 public report (prior-year report showing the team’s reporting practice and comparable metrics).
